subject: Re: Change generic signature of assert that
msgSnippet: Me too, it does generally work fine. It works fine for classes without generic parameters (they just have to be of the same type). Where it broke down is when
messageBody:
Me too, it does generally work fine. It works fine for classes without generic parameters (they just have to be of the same type). Where it broke down is when comparing classes with generic parameters. The workaround was:

Map<String, Class<? extends Serializable>> result = null;
Matcher matches = hasEntry("Key", java.util.Date.class);
assertThat(result, matches);

It makes a compiler warning that has to be suppressed, but it gets around the problem.

>
> For the record,

> corner cases all that often. This probably means that I've learned to
> keep away from problem areas, but also means that it's fairly possible
> to keep away from problem areas.
>
> Didn't want to leave the thread on the impression that everyone agrees
> that assertThat is totally broken in JUnit.
>
> David Saff
